subject: Re: QS news update
msgSnippet: ... Incredibly it is Spanish that has more accents and of greater variety than English because those nations are older and integrated larger numbers of native
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...> wrote:

>
>I think that is just it, as I am coming to see. English has a greater
>variety of accents than Spanish. So we either have to have a rigid
>spelling system or allow variations in spelling.
>

Incredibly it is Spanish that has more accents and of greater variety
than English because those nations are older and integrated larger
numbers of native inhabitants. So vast that even "ll" is pronounced as
"ee" by some and yet "j" by others! It is the *way* in which the
accents vary that makes a single uniform writing system in English
difficult; we have not only merged vowels but we have done so
differently in different countries and this has been our undoing.


>
> I thought the major difference would be with words like "bath." But
with
> Australians, it might be some other set. So I can get used to seeing
> words like "bath" spelled differently, but then do I have to get use to
> another set for Australians?
>

You do not. "bath" can only be spelled with #30 and #32

Of course the bath problem is incurable in any spelling reform project:
- Either you have separate letters for the "trap" sound and the "palm"
sound in which case for the word "bath" some speakers will use one and
some the other; this is the QS approach.
- Or you have just one letter to represent both the "trap" and "bath"
sound in which case "moss" and "mass" will be spelled the same. An
extreme solution would be to imitate Semitic languages and write
without vowels. But English is not designed for this and will not
work. jst try t rd ths sntns.

There are other issues in this vein but they do not seriously affect
readability in QS.



>
> But the difference in spelling between British and American English
[TO] is
> almost non-existent. I am guessing that one could read an entire
article
> and not come across a difference. In contrast, one could come across a
> different spelling between a British and American scribe in QS nearly
> every sentence. That could slow down your reading.
>

The difference between American and UK QS spelling is essentially only
in "bath" "lot" and "cloth" sounds. (If there were no letter "Ox" then
the only difference would be "bath"). I don't know if this results in
a large percentage of words on a typical page having even a single
letter difference but I contend the number is low and readability is
high. We will have to compare texts side by side to prove this one way
or another.


>
> More practically in my case, I need to know what letter to use in words
> like "Pot" so that readers from all over the world can read the news
> relatively easy. Using my Boston accent as a guide seems unwise.
>

#32, #33 and #34 are interchangeable for this category of sound. It is
safe to write based on the Boston accent because it is guaranteed to
use one of these letters for the word "pot".
In particular, if "pot" sounds like "palm" you will use #32 ah, if not
but it sounds like "thought" then use #33 Awe and if it does not sound
like "thought" either then use #34 Ox. A printout of the sample words
for QS letter is much easier and faster to follow than such a
prose description and makes errors less likely.
